spanishExample: A veces tienes una idea que no podrías hacer.
englishTranslation: Sometimes you have an idea that you wouldn’t be able to do.
vocabIncluded: podrías: "would be able", "you would be able" (Poder, conditional, 2nd person)

spanishExample: A veces yo mismo lo hago.
englishTranslation: Sometimes I do it myself.
vocabIncluded: mismo: adjective meaning "herself", "myself", etc. for emphasis (e.g. "yo misma")

spanishExample: Al mismo tiempo, teníamos un acuerdo.
englishTranslation: At the same time, we had an agreement.
vocabIncluded: al mismo tiempo: "at the same time" (idiom)

spanishExample: Cuando eran *kids,* podían *to eat* mucho.
englishTranslation: When they were kids, they were able to eat a lot.
vocabIncluded: podían: "were able", "they were able" (Poder, imperfect, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: El lugar podrá ser seguro.
englishTranslation: The place will be able to be safe.
vocabIncluded: podrá: "will be able", "he/she/it will be able" (Poder, future, 3rd person)
seguro: adjective meaning "safe" or "secure" when used with Ser

spanishExample: Él podrá hacer lo mismo una vez que lo haga con cuidado.
englishTranslation: He will be able to do the same once he does it carefully.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
podrá: "will be able", "he/she/it will be able" (Poder, future, 3rd person)
una vez que: idiom meaning "once", right before another phrase

spanishExample: Está claro que estaremos felices una vez que lo hagamos.
englishTranslation: It’s clear that we’ll be happy once we do it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
claro: adjective meaning "clear" when used with Estar
estaremos: "will be", "we will be" (Estar, future, 1st person plural)
una vez que: idiom meaning "once", right before another phrase

spanishExample: Está claro que este es un lugar seguro.
englishTranslation: It’s clear that this is a safe place.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
claro: adjective meaning "clear" when used with Estar
seguro: adjective meaning "safe" or "secure" when used with Ser

spanishExample: Estábamos felices cuando *we finished* nuestro trabajo.
englishTranslation: We were happy when we finished our work.

spanishExample: Estoy solo de vez en cuando.
englishTranslation: I am lonely(m) once in a while.
vocabIncluded: de vez en cuando: "once in a while" (idiom)

spanishExample: Ha podido estar sola con la que tenía.
englishTranslation: She has been able to be alone with the one(f) that she had.
vocabIncluded: "la que" to mean "which" after a preposition
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: *I hope* que puedan hacer lo que yo pude hacer ese día.
englishTranslation: I hope they can do what I was able to do that day.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pude: "was able / managed", "I was able / managed" (Poder, preterite, 1st person)
puedan: "be able", "they be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: *I wanted* que ella pudiera hacer todo a la vez.
englishTranslation: I wanted her to be able to do everything at once.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pudiera: "were able", "he/she/it were able" (Poder, subjunctive past, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Mi amigo pudo hacerlo a la vez.
englishTranslation: My friend was able to do it at once.
vocabIncluded: pudo: "was able / managed", "he/she/it was able / managed" (Poder, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No estoy seguro de que podamos hacerlo ya mismo.
englishTranslation: I’m not sure we can do it this instant.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
podamos: "be able", "we be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 1st person plural)
seguro: adjective meaning "sure" when used with Estar

spanishExample: No pudo estar ahí de una vez por todas.
englishTranslation: He wasn’t able to be there once and for all.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
de una vez por todas: "once and for all" (idiom)
pudo: "was able / managed", "he/she/it was able / managed" (Poder, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No, no podré ir.
englishTranslation: No, I won’t be able to go.
vocabIncluded: podré: "will be able", "I will be able" (Poder, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: Nosotros mismos podemos hacerlo.
englishTranslation: We ourselves can do it.
vocabIncluded: mismo: adjective meaning "herself", "myself", etc. for emphasis (e.g. "yo misma")

spanishExample: Podía estar seguro de vez en cuando.
englishTranslation: I was able to be sure once in a while.
vocabIncluded: de vez en cuando: "once in a while" (idiom)
podía: "was able", "I was able" (Poder, imperfect, 1st person)
seguro: adjective meaning "sure" when used with Estar

spanishExample: Podías hacerlo, pero ya no puedes.
englishTranslation: You were able to do it, but you aren’t able anymore.
vocabIncluded: podías: "were able", "you were able" (Poder, imperfect, 2nd person)
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Podrían ser la misma cosa.
englishTranslation: They would be able to be the same thing.
vocabIncluded: podrían: "would be able", "they would be able" (Poder, conditional, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Pueden ir ya mismo.
englishTranslation: They can go this instant.

spanishExample: Sería mejor si lo hiciera de una vez por todas.
englishTranslation: It would be better if I did it once and for all.
vocabIncluded: de una vez por todas: "once and for all" (idiom)
sería: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Ser, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Tienes razón, puedo hacerlo al mismo tiempo.
englishTranslation: You’re right, I can do it at the same time.
vocabIncluded: al mismo tiempo: "at the same time" (idiom)
tener razón: "to be right" (idiom, lit. "to have reason")
